title: Gaua

meta_description: Gaua is an active stratovolcano in Vanuatu with a 6x9 km caldera, crater lake, and 18 eruptions since 1962. Explore its eruption history, hazards, and remote island setting.

quick_answer.what: Gaua (also known as Santa Maria) is an active stratovolcano forming a roughly 20-km-diameter island in the Banks Islands group of northern Vanuatu, featuring a 6 × 9 km summit caldera with a crater lake and the active cone of Mount Garet.
quick_answer.status: Active — last erupted in 2022. Has been in a state of frequent eruption since 1962, with 18 recorded events.
quick_answer.famous_for: Its remote island setting, the active Mount Garet cone within a flooded caldera, and a sustained period of eruptive activity since 1962 that has periodically forced evacuations of the island's small population.
quick_answer.danger_level: Moderate — approximately 2,500–3,000 people live on the island, primarily in coastal villages. Eruptions have caused temporary evacuations and ashfall damage to crops.

overview.content: Gaua (also known as Santa Maria Island) is an active stratovolcano forming a roughly 20-km-diameter island in the Banks Islands group of northern Vanuatu, approximately 350 km north of the capital Port Vila. Rising to 729 m (2,392 ft) at the rim of its 6 × 9 km summit caldera, Gaua is one of the most persistently active volcanoes in the southwestern Pacific. The caldera contains Lake Letas — a crescent-shaped lake approximately 5 km² in area that is the largest lake in Vanuatu — and the active volcanic cone of Mount Garet (or Garat), which rises from the caldera floor in its southwestern quadrant. Since emerging from a long dormancy in 1962, Mount Garet has erupted 18 times, maintaining a pattern of Strombolian and phreatomagmatic activity that periodically blankets portions of the island in ash, damages food gardens, and forces temporary evacuations of the island's approximately 2,500–3,000 residents. Gaua sits along the Vanuatu volcanic arc, where the Australian Plate subducts beneath the Pacific Plate, part of the same tectonic system that generates volcanic activity across the southwestern Pacific from New Zealand to Papua New Guinea. The island's extreme remoteness — accessible only by small aircraft or inter-island cargo vessels — amplifies the challenge of monitoring and managing volcanic risk for its subsistence-farming population.

geology_and_formation.content: Gaua is constructed on the Vanuatu volcanic arc, generated by the westward subduction of the Australian Plate beneath the Pacific Plate at the New Hebrides Trench. The island represents the emergent summit of a large submarine volcano rising from the floor of the Coral Sea. The main edifice is basaltic-to-andesitic, typical of the intermediate-composition magmas produced in island arc settings. The roughly 700-m-deep caldera formed through quiet collapse (rather than a single catastrophic eruption) and was subsequently modified by extensive ash eruptions. Small vents near the caldera rim fed Pleistocene lava flows that reached the coast on several sides, and littoral cones formed where these flows entered the ocean. The currently active Mount Garet cone has been constructed within the southwestern part of the caldera, and its growth — along with that of other small cinder cones — has progressively reduced the lake area, creating the present crescent-shaped Lake Letas.

eruption_history_overview.content: Gaua's recorded eruption history begins in 1962, when activity from a vent high on the SE flank of Mount Garet ended a long period of dormancy — the volcano had apparently been quiet since at least European contact in the early 19th century. Since 1962, Mount Garet has erupted 18 times through 2022, averaging one eruption every 3–4 years. Most events have been VEI 1–2 (Strombolian explosions and minor ash emissions), with the strongest recorded eruption reaching VEI 3 in 1965. Activity is concentrated at the summit pit craters of Mount Garet, though some eruptions have involved upper-flank vents. The eruptions follow a pattern of intermittent Strombolian to Vulcanian explosions, ash emission, and occasional lava effusion within the caldera.

subsections.title: The 1962 Reawakening and 1965 VEI 3 Eruption
subsections.content: After a long dormancy of unknown duration, Gaua reawakened on July 16, 1962, with eruptions from a vent on the upper SE flank of Mount Garet. This initial VEI 2 event was followed by near-annual eruptions through the 1960s and 1970s. The most significant early eruption occurred on September 27, 1965, reaching VEI 3 — the strongest recorded event at Gaua. This eruption produced substantial ash columns and tephra fall that affected the island's villages and food gardens.

subsections.title: The 2009–2010 Eruption and Island Evacuation
subsections.content: A significant eruption beginning September 27, 2009, and continuing into 2010 produced sustained ash emissions from Mount Garet that severely impacted the island's population. Heavy ashfall damaged water supplies, contaminated food gardens (the primary subsistence source for villagers), and raised concerns about respiratory health. The Vanuatu government and international aid organizations assisted with partial evacuations and food relief. Acid rain from the volcanic gases damaged crops and corrugated iron roofing. This eruption highlighted the vulnerability of Gaua's isolated community to even moderate volcanic activity.

subsections.title: Recent Activity (2011–2022)
subsections.content: Gaua has continued its pattern of frequent, low-level eruptions into the 2020s. VEI 1 events were recorded in 2011, 2021, and 2022, with Mount Garet producing intermittent Strombolian explosions and ash plumes. The Vanuatu Meteorology and Geo-Hazards Department (VMGD) maintains the volcano at Alert Level 1 or 2 (minor unrest to moderate activity) during these episodes. Each event prompts ash advisories, exclusion zones around the summit, and monitoring of impacts on the island's villages.

current_status_and_monitoring.content: Gaua is monitored by the Vanuatu Meteorology and Geo-Hazards Department (VMGD), which maintains a seismic station on the island and conducts periodic field surveys. Satellite remote sensing (thermal anomaly detection and SO₂ monitoring) provides additional surveillance. The VMGD volcanic alert level system ranges from 0 (normal) to 5 (very large eruption). Gaua typically fluctuates between levels 1 and 2, reflecting the volcano's persistent low-level unrest. The most recent eruption (May 2022) was a VEI 1 event at Mount Garet. Monitoring challenges include the island's remoteness, limited communications infrastructure, and the difficulty of maintaining ground-based instruments in a tropical environment.

hazards_and_risk_assessment.content: Volcanic hazards on Gaua include ashfall (the most frequent and impactful hazard, damaging subsistence gardens and water supplies), Strombolian projectiles (dangerous within 1–3 km of the active vents), volcanic gas emissions (SO₂ and HCl affecting air quality and causing acid rain), potential lahars (if eruptions interact with Lake Letas or heavy tropical rainfall mobilizes deposits), and — in a worst-case scenario — pyroclastic flows from a larger eruption. The approximately 2,500–3,000 residents live in coastal villages, 5–10 km from the active vent, providing some buffer from summit hazards. However, ashfall can blanket the entire island, and the subsistence-based economy means that crop damage translates directly into food insecurity. Evacuation is complicated by the island's remoteness and limited transport — there is a small airstrip and irregular boat service.

geography_and_physical_description.content: Gaua forms a roughly circular island approximately 20 km in diameter, rising from the seafloor to a maximum elevation of 729 m at the caldera rim. The 6 × 9 km summit caldera contains Lake Letas, Vanuatu's largest lake, which wraps in a crescent shape around the active Mount Garet cone. Mount Garet rises approximately 300 m above the caldera floor and features three pit craters across its summit area. The outer slopes of the island are cloaked in dense tropical forest, descending to narrow coastal plains where the island's villages are located. Coral reefs fringe much of the coastline. The interior is largely uninhabited, with the caldera and Mount Garet forming a barren volcanic landscape surrounded by the lush green of the outer slopes.

cultural_significance.content: Gaua's small population of ni-Vanuatu (indigenous Melanesian people) has coexisted with volcanic activity for generations. Traditional knowledge of the volcano's behavior is passed through oral history, and communities have developed adaptive strategies for living with periodic ashfall and evacuation. The island is known for its distinctive cultural practices, including water music (women creating rhythmic sounds by slapping the ocean surface) and traditional sand drawing, which is recognized by UNESCO as an intangible cultural heritage of Vanuatu. The volcano itself features in local cosmology and origin stories.

visiting_and_tourism.content: Gaua is one of the more remote and less-visited volcanic islands in Vanuatu, though it attracts occasional adventurous travelers. Access is via small aircraft from Port Vila or Luganville to the island's airstrip, or by inter-island cargo boat. There are no formal hotels — visitors arrange accommodation with local families through community-based tourism. The trek to the caldera rim and Mount Garet is a challenging full-day excursion through dense tropical forest with local guides. Lake Letas can be reached by a separate trail. Visitors should check the current volcanic alert level with the VMGD before planning a visit, as access to the caldera may be restricted during periods of elevated activity.

nearby_volcanoes.content: Gaua is part of the Vanuatu volcanic arc, one of the most volcanically active island chains in the world. Nearby volcanoes include Ambrym (approximately 200 km to the south), which maintains some of the world's most active lava lakes, and Ambae (Aoba), which erupted in 2017–2018 forcing the evacuation of the entire island's population of approximately 11,000 people. Lopevi and Yasur (on Tanna island) are other frequently active Vanuatu volcanoes. The arc is generated by the subduction of the Australian Plate at the New Hebrides Trench, producing a chain of approximately 12 historically active volcanic islands.

facts: Gaua has erupted 18 times since 1962, averaging one eruption every 3–4 years — making it one of the most frequently active volcanoes in the southwestern Pacific.
Lake Letas, the crescent-shaped crater lake within Gaua's caldera, is the largest lake in Vanuatu with a surface area of approximately 5 km².
The island's population of approximately 2,500–3,000 subsistence farmers has been periodically evacuated due to volcanic ashfall that destroys food gardens — their primary food source.
Gaua's 6 × 9 km summit caldera was formed by quiet collapse rather than a single catastrophic eruption, unlike many calderas around the world.
Mount Garet, the active cone within the caldera, has three pit craters across its summit and has been the source of all recorded eruptions.
The island was dormant for an unknown period before 1962, when eruptions resumed and have continued intermittently ever since.
Gaua is known for its unique cultural practice of water music, where women create rhythmic sounds by slapping the ocean surface — a tradition recognized by UNESCO.
Volcanic acid rain from SO₂ emissions during eruptions corrodes metal roofing and contaminates rainwater collection systems — the island's primary water source.
The Vanuatu volcanic arc, of which Gaua is part, contains approximately 12 historically active volcanic islands along the New Hebrides Trench subduction zone.
Gaua's remoteness means eruption response depends heavily on small aircraft and inter-island boats — evacuation during bad weather can be extremely difficult.
Littoral cones formed where Pleistocene lava flows from caldera-rim vents reached the ocean, creating distinctive coastal formations around the island.
In 2009–2010, heavy ashfall from Mount Garet severely damaged the island's food supply, requiring international humanitarian assistance for the community.

faqs.question: Is Gaua volcano still active?
faqs.answer: Yes, Gaua is one of the most frequently active volcanoes in Vanuatu. Since reawakening in 1962, Mount Garet (the active cone within the caldera) has erupted 18 times through 2022, averaging roughly one eruption every 3–4 years. The most recent eruption was a VEI 1 event in May 2022. Between eruptions, the volcano typically exhibits fumarolic activity and minor seismicity. The Vanuatu Meteorology and Geo-Hazards Department maintains monitoring and issues alert levels.

faqs.question: Where is Gaua located?
faqs.answer: Gaua (also known as Santa Maria) is an island volcano in the Banks Islands group of northern Vanuatu, a Pacific island nation located east of Australia and northeast of New Caledonia. It sits at approximately 14.28°S, 167.51°E, roughly 350 km north of the capital Port Vila. The island is accessible by small aircraft or inter-island boat, and its approximately 2,500–3,000 residents live in coastal villages around the island's perimeter.

faqs.question: What is Lake Letas?
faqs.answer: Lake Letas is a crescent-shaped volcanic crater lake within Gaua's 6 × 9 km summit caldera. With a surface area of approximately 5 km², it is the largest lake in Vanuatu. The lake wraps around the active Mount Garet cone, which has grown within the caldera and progressively reduced the lake's size. Lake Letas sits at an elevation of approximately 400 m and is surrounded by dense tropical vegetation on the outer caldera walls and barren volcanic terrain near Mount Garet.

faqs.question: Is it safe to visit Gaua?
faqs.answer: Visiting Gaua requires careful planning and awareness of volcanic risk. During periods of low activity (Alert Level 0–1), the island is generally safe for visitors staying in the coastal villages, though treks to the caldera and Mount Garet should be undertaken only with local guides and after checking the current alert level with the VMGD. During elevated activity (Alert Level 2+), exclusion zones are established around the summit, and ashfall may affect the entire island. The island's remoteness means medical facilities and evacuation options are very limited.

faqs.question: How many people live on Gaua?
faqs.answer: Approximately 2,500–3,000 people live on Gaua, primarily in small coastal villages around the island's perimeter. The population practices subsistence farming, growing taro, yam, banana, and coconut as staple crops. This subsistence-based lifestyle makes the community highly vulnerable to volcanic ashfall, which can destroy food gardens and contaminate water supplies. During significant eruptions (such as 2009–2010), partial evacuations and international food aid have been necessary.

faqs.question: What type of volcano is Gaua?
faqs.answer: Gaua is a stratovolcano — a composite volcanic cone built from alternating layers of lava flows, tephra, and volcanic debris. The island-forming edifice rises from the seafloor to 729 m above sea level, crowned by a 6 × 9 km summit caldera that contains Lake Letas and the active Mount Garet cone. The rock composition is andesitic to basaltic andesitic, typical of island arc volcanoes generated by subduction. Eruptions are primarily Strombolian to Vulcanian in character.
